text: hi everyone shapheny take tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new indigo
d'souza album any shape you take this is
the newest full-length lp from north
carolina singer and songwriter indigo
d'souza her second full length which is
out now via saddle creek a project that
i've been looking forward to getting
into thanks to its rave reviews and
decent teasers de souza's production
this time around is sounding a lot
sharper and more colorful since that
saddle creek bump too but all this extra
industry push hasn't resulted in the
total and complete artistic aha moment i
guess i was hoping for don't get me
wrong any shape you take is a solid
record that's worthy of attention and
ultimately feels like a high-def version
of the lo-fi indie rock found on her
debut i love my mom but with that change
we didn't lose that kind of organic and
raw feel it is a slight letdown though
that a few of the instrumentals don't
really add up to much more than
boilerplate for the indie genre there
are some spots where the writing leaves
something to be desired too like on the
song die slash cry which is a pretty
straightforward rock cut with some
americana flavored guitar licks popping
in here and there the vocal performance
has a tangy timbre to it that takes me
back to the 90s and while i do like the
sentiment of the song the refrain itself
lyrically is painfully basic i'd rather
die than see you cry than see you cry
than see you cry sure it does take on a
darker angle in the second half with i'd
rather die before you die but those
lyrics don't really sit all that well
with me either though i will say they
play a part in a larger portrait of
d'souza's feelings and emotions on this
lp where she comes off very much like a
giver somebody who is always wanting to
take the emotional brunt of a situation
so yes while i do have my issues with
this track a bigger problem is the song
pretty pictures for one the instrumental
on this track sounds like something fit
for a sad scene out of a bad rom-com
it's also essentially a breakup song
which is fine but the lyrics are so on
the nose and so lacking in any personal
details it sounds almost like an ad for
breaking up breaking up and getting back
together breaking up with someone you
love because you know it's gonna be for
the better but it's so hard to give it
up and lyrically things don't really get
that much deeper on the rest of the
track too again the writing doesn't feel
like it's so much in reference to a
specific breakup but like breaking up as
an abstract or as a construct like heard
second hand from somebody else the
writing on real pain isn't that much
better either though i think this track
does come to a more interesting climax
with this agonized bridge of heavy
droney guitars screams sound effects and
what sounds like chatter 2 there's also
a refrain that brings the track to a
triumphant end the song bad dream is
pretty climactic as well with d'souza
launching into one of the more
impassioned vocal performances on the
record i love the heavy and fuzzy
cathartic guitar layers all over this
track too they really call back to
indy's classic low-fi 90s stomping
grounds with a full warm sort of
euphoric sound things pick up on the
song late night crawler 2 not only with
one of the most dynamic instrumentals on
the lp but some actually compelling
lyrics about separating as well maybe
we're bigger than staying on the very
same island maybe we're bigger than
staying in the very same place and i
love how the track ends with one of
these bars of i won't be cruel when you
find that you don't need a girl to feel
better which really conveys obviously
this feeling of tragedy on the song but
again with de souza's emotions across
the record generally there's also this
sense of forgiveness and understanding
no matter what life is kind of throwing
her way the song hold you was a teaser
to this record and in the track list i
found it to be a pretty refreshing
change of pace though i anticipated
there would be more tracks on this lp
along the lines of this one it features
some really slick syncopated drums and
guitar leads the grooves are pretty
danceable and overall the song brings
more of a pop vibe d'souza even smooths
out her vocal delivery a bit more to fit
along with the style i love the assuring
lyrics on the track and it's easily one
of the most feel-good and infectious
spots on the project too meanwhile the
closing track is the epitome of doneness
i mean the title of it is literally kill
me it features some of the grandest and
most chaotic guitar riffs which uh kind
of have their edge taken off by some
very sweet vocal harmonies there's so
much emotional anguish being expressed
on this track too which is leading
d'souza to right in this way where she's
just saying like look i'm done kill me
make it over
been there look uh overall i feel like
this is a very solid indie rock record
that is worth the hype that it's been
getting so far though maybe it didn't
personally meet my expectations
stylistically it's not all that
inventive but there are strong displays
of emotion across the project the
production's fine the performances are
pretty raw and the songs are well
arranged and structured yeah there are
some spots where the lyrics are lacking
or a little bit too repetitive but there
are even more spots where they're worth
diving into like on the opener 17 where
d'souza actually delivers a bit of a
synth pop number with some really
creative vocal manipulations that uh
are some of the most refreshing sounds
on the entire record i hope it's not an
idea that she abandons on
future projects i'd love to hear that
come back especially since her vocals
are so good they still showcase a lot of
character even as they're altered
feeling a light to decent seven on this
one tran position have you given this
album a listen did you love it did you
hate it what would you rate it you're
the best you're the best what should i
review next hit the like if you like
please subscribe and please don't cry
hit the bell as well over here next to
my head it's another video you can check
out hit that up or the link to subscribe
to the channel anthony fantano indigo
d'souza forever
